title: Fix: 3537 exempts authoritative Pydantic models from schema contracts cheks
body:
## Description
- remove all Pydantic v1 compatibility code — the codebase now requires and uses only Pydantic v2 APIs
- add support for Pydantic models with discriminated union `RootModel` types in schema generation and contract enforcement
- rework schema contract handling to separate resource-defined hints from data-derived hints, so Pydantic model columns bypass contract checks when marked as authoritative
- rewrite `merge_table` to work without `diff_table`, fixing reference merging and treating `incremental` as a compound property
- suppress Pydantic deprecation warnings and fix instance-level attribute access to prepare for Pydantic v3
- resolves #3537 (if model authoritative)
- supports Pydantic models with discriminated fields to validate event streams
- allow Pydantic models on arrow and model items
- fully implement schema contracts on model items
- removes dead Pydantic 1 code paths
- resolves issues with Athena not falling back to append in some cases
head__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️

title: feat: composable marimo widgets
body:
## Summary
This adds composable widgets to `dlt` built with `marimo`. A widget is **composable** because you can give it inputs and read its outputs. For `marimo < 0.19`, it wasn't possible to pass inputs.

This follows-up #3021 (read-only widgets) and #3080 (closed in favor of this one)

## Content
- instructions on how to create widgets
- updated previous read-only widgets (schema viewer and load package viewer)
- add simple pipeline selector widget
- add a dependency to `mowidgets`, which implements the widget logic. It's MIT-licensed library and hosted on GitHub. I created it on my personal time.

## Open question
I don't think creating a new `dlt[widgets]` group is the best idea. This should probably be in `dlt[workspace]`. Though, we would need to bump the `marimo` notebook significantly from 0.14 to 0.19. IMHO, we shouldn't support old dependencies in dev-tooling (e.g., drop old marimo versions). This is different than pipelines, sources, and destinations where backwards compatibility is essential

## Next steps
- Build more "single-purpose" widgets
- Rebuild the dlt Dashboard to use composable widgets. 
  - There is no immediate gain, but it will improve maintainability and ensure parity between "dashboard" and "interactive widgets" moving forward
- Add public documentation
- Add tests to individual widgets, especially those used in the dashboard. We can focus on critical paths.

---

<!-- continue-task-summary-start -->
**Continue Tasks:** ✅ 2 no changes — [View all](https://hub.continue.dev/inbox?pr=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fdlt-hub%2Fdlt%2Fpull%2F3613&utm_source=github_pr&utm_medium=pr_body&utm_campaign=continue_tasks)
<!-- continue-task-summary-end -->

title: Add agent checks for automated PR review
body:
## Description

Add 14 agent check files in `.continue/agents/` for automated PR review. These checks encode project-specific conventions that require human judgment — things that existing linters and CI can't catch.

### Checks included

| Check | What it reviews |
|---|---|
| `identifier-normalization` | All identifiers pass through schema naming normalizer |
| `module-hierarchy` | `dlt/common/` stays generic, protocols for cross-module interfaces |
| `thread-safety` | Concurrent code paths (load jobs, sinks) are thread-safe |
| `deprecation-guidelines` | Breaking changes follow DltDeprecationWarning lifecycle |
| `destination-implementation` | New destinations follow factory/config/client pattern |
| `configuration-patterns` | @configspec usage, TSecretValue typing, credential specs |
| `exception-handling` | DltException hierarchy with Terminal/Transient mixins |
| `public-api-exports` | New public items added to `__all__` |
| `column-hints-merging` | Adapter hints merge correctly instead of overwriting |
| `cli-output-conventions` | CLI uses fmt not logger, error messages use backticks |
| `documentation-sync` | User-facing changes have corresponding docs |
| `test-coverage` | Tests are parallel-safe, use uniq_id, cover edge cases |
| `security-review` | No hardcoded creds, SQL injection prevention |
| `agent-docs-maintenance` | Agent check files stay current when conventions change |

Also updates `.gitignore` to track `.continue/agents/` while ignoring other `.continue/` contents.

## Related Issues

N/A — this adds AI-assisted review infrastructure.

## Additional Context

Each check was derived from:
- Analyzing `CONTRIBUTING.md`, `tox.ini`, `mypy.ini`, CI workflows
- Reviewing comments on ~30 recent merged PRs to identify recurring reviewer feedback
- Understanding the destination/configuration/schema architecture

Checks intentionally exclude anything already caught by deterministic CI tools (mypy, flake8, uv lock, etc.).

---

<!-- continue-task-summary-end -->

title: feat: `Dataset.write()`
body:
Users of `dlt.Dataset` want a simple way to write data back to the dataset.

Use cases:
- manually review data and push corrected records
- simple way to add records if you don't have access to the original `dlt.Pipeline` used to create the dataset

## Other motivations
This interface will simplify data-centric operations involved in:
- storing data quality checks results on destination
- creating a graph of datasets where the "internal pipeline" of dataset is used
- integrate with orchestration frameworks

## Specs
- Look at `WritableDataset.save()` from `dlt-plus`
- Add `Dataset.write()` in `dlt` (this aligns with `pipeline.run()` operation)
  - Alternatives: `.write_to()`, `.load_into()`, `.load_table()`
- create an internal `dlt.Pipeline` named `_dlt_dataset_{dataset_name}`
- find a way for the internal pipeline to use the `dlt.Schema` from the `dlt.Dataset` instance; this way, this schema should evolve when `Dataset.load()` is used
- potential API
  ```python
  def write(
    self: dlt.Dataset,
    data: TDataItems,
    *,
    table_name: str,
    write_disposition: TWriteDisposition = "append",
    normalize: bool = False,
  ) -> LoadInfo: ...
  ```
  - `write_disposition` is useful to determine if we should append or modify existing records
  - `normalize` allows the user to decide to enable normalization (which might create more tables)
- can accept a `dlt.Relation` as input


## Out of scope
- `Dataset.load()` doesn't have to support 1-to-1 the `dlt.Pipeline.run()` method; if user needs full range of config, then they should create a pipeline
head__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️
base__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️

title: Experiments: wasm dashboard
body:
This is a standalone trace dashboard that takes a trace json path and uses that json to render the trace section.

- It can be locally ran with ` uv run marimo run dlt/_workspace/helpers/dashboard/trace_dashboard.py -- --trace-url http://localhost:8765/exported_trace.json` 
- Exported to a wasm format with `uv run marimo export html-wasm dlt/_workspace/helpers/dashboard/trace_dashboard.py -o tmp/`
- And served with `python -m http.server --directory tmp` + the `trace_url` arg

> If ran locally, the json will need to be served on a different port, or be in the same origin in `tmp/`

title: feat: SQLGlot for DDL parsing
body:
Relates to #2561 

## Description
This maps dlt hints to SQLGlot DDL expressions. This internal feature could enable future usage:

### Table discovery
To enable `@dlt.transformation`, it's useful to know about tables manages outside of dlt.

It would make sense to discover from the `dlt.Dataset` API to add tables to its schema. Discovery should be limited to the same "database/dataset" namespace on the destination. Retrieving DDL from destination is a very cheap operation.

We would need a new hint for external tables.

tentative API.
```python
dataset = dlt.Dataset(...)
table_foo = dataset.table("foo")  # regular access
table_bar = dataset.table("bar")  # raise TableNotExist

dataset.discover()  # all tables within "database/dataset" namespace
dataset.discover("bar")  # single specific table
dataset.discover(["bar", "baz"])  # multiple specific tables 
dataset.discover(pattern="ba.*")  # unknown number using regex

table_bar = dataset.table("bar")  # succeeds because table is now in schema
```
This effect is persisted to the schema storage and the destination.

### Table creation
We have a lot of templated SQL strings for destination clients. We also use destination-specific SDK libraries.

Generating DDL from dlt hints could simplify internals and help with maintenance. This potentially simplifies supporting and testing new SQL backends.

More importantly, `dlt -> DDL` allows more powerful user configuration (e.g., create an index).
head__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️
base__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️

title: Redshift fix: Use correct view to determine schema existence
body:
## Description

Currently, the RedshiftSqlClient relies on `INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA` to determine if a schema exists. Unfortunately, this is not listing all the schemas (that's why there is this workaround, where the `public` schema is handled explicitly). The current way can cause errors, if the schema already exists, but is not listed in `INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA` when attempting to create it. 

To fix this, I've added added a condition that checks if the schema exists using `svv_redshift_schemas`, which lists schemas accessible to the current user (see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/latest/dg/r_SVV_REDSHIFT_SCHEMAS.html). I'm not aware if there are older Redshift versions, that do not have `svv_redshift_schemas`. Therefore, the old behaviour was preserved if the view does not exists. 

### Result
Redshift pipelines are less prone to intermittent “schema already exists” failures while keeping the previous behavior as a fallback when `svv_redshift_schemas` is not available/visible.

Code has been formatted using the black formatter. Please let me know if there's something else to be done.
head__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️
base__repo__description: data load tool (dlt) is an open source Python library that makes data loading easy 🛠️

-->
### Description
dlt users want to pass SQLAlchemy engine arguments for:
1. SQL sources (sql_database and sql_table)
2. SQL destination


### Summary of Changes

This PR introduces support for configuring SQLAlchemy engine arguments across both sources and destinations, addressing a long-standing usability gap:

- **Sources (`sql_database`, `sql_table`)**
  - Added a new parameter `engine_kwargs`, forwarded directly to `sqlalchemy.create_engine()`.
  - Supports configuring reflection behavior and extraction for the SQLAlchemy backend.
  - Includes comprehensive tests:
    - invalid kwargs propagation  
    - reflection failure  
    - SQLite timeout enforcement  
    - interaction with backend_kwargs when using non-SQLAlchemy backends  
    - SQLAlchemy echo logging behavior

- **Destination (SQLAlchemy)**
  - Adds missing documentation for existing `engine_args`.
  - Adds tests to verify correct behavior for both in-memory and file-based SQLite destinations using `engine_args`.

- **Documentation**
  - Adds new docs for source-side `engine_kwargs`.
  - Adds new docs for destination-side `engine_args`.
  - Clarifies that source and destination engines are separate and configured independently.

**Question:** To reduce user confusion, should the source parameter be named `engine_kwargs` (current) or unified as `engine_args` (matching the destination)?

<!--
Please link any related issues. This helps us keep the PR focused and merge it faster.
-->
### Related Issues

- Resolves #3187

<!--
Provide any additional context about the PR here.
-->

<!--
Please ensure that
    - you have read the Contributing to dlt guide.
    - you have run the tests locally and they have passed before submitting your PR.
-->

title: chore/Remove private key and replace with double b64 encoded key to avoid github ban in tests

- implementation: currently, this PR modifies the default behaviour when dlt type is decimal with both precision and scale being None. This is backwards incompatible, so instead of making this new logic the default, it should only work for some opt-in flag/config/...
- tests: add a test for oracle source and snowflake destination to ensure that a column with otherwise unsupported values will work. Oracle type should be `NUMBER()`, we should ensure that a `DECFLOAT` column on Snowflake gets created and that 2 values (one with 30 signs before the comma and another with 30 signs after) are transferred exactly, without loss of data

title: fix(clickhouse): use CREATE OR REPLACE for merge temp tables
body:
### Description

On replicated ClickHouse clusters (including ClickHouse Cloud), `DROP TABLE ... SYNC` can take 2+ seconds due to replication coordination overhead. This causes significant latency in high-frequency pipelines using merge disposition.

This PR replaces the `DROP TABLE IF EXISTS ... SYNC; CREATE TABLE ...` pattern with `CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE`, which uses the Atomic database engine's atomic swap mechanism via `renameat2()`. The swap is nearly instant and the old table is cleaned up asynchronously.

### Related Issues

- Resolves #3562

### Additional Context

The Atomic database engine (default since ClickHouse 20.5, mandatory on Cloud) decouples table names from storage paths via UUIDs. `CREATE OR REPLACE` atomically swaps metadata entries — no need to wait for the old table deletion.

title: Add `huggingface()` destination
body:
<!--
Thank you for submitting a pull request! Please provide a brief description of your changes below.
-->
### Description

Add `huggingface()` destination

```python
from dlt.destinations import huggingface

destination = huggingface(dataset_name="lhoestq/dlt-experiment")
```

It writes the files as `"data/{split}-xxxxx-of-nnnnn.parquet"` to match the usual/default HF structure, but we could use whatever structure and add the associated file pattern in YAML (needed for the HF Dataset Viewer) instead if it makes sense.

It also adds the default Parquet value:
- `use_content_defined_chunking=True` -> for [Parquet CDC](https://huggingface.co/blog/parquet-cdc)
- `write_page_index=True` -> this allows better filtering and random access, esp. in the HF Dataset Viewer

**Question 1**: `use_content_defined_chunking` is only available in recent versions of `pyarrow`, how would you like this to be handled ?

**Question 2**: is there a way for the JobClient to retrieve information from the jobs ? I would like each job to pre-upload the files and the JobClient to `commit()` once the jobs are all done, and for this I need each job to return some information about the pre-upload step (more precisely, the id of each remote file after pre-upload)

<!--
Please link any related issues. This helps us keep the PR focused and merge it faster.
-->
### Related Issues

- related to https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/pull/3391 which adds HF filesystem support
- continuation of https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/issues/1227

3. Confirm that reviewer would be able to create new parallel safe tests using the mentioned python test helpers in the contributing guide

title: feat/3155 history
body:
### Description

This PR introduces the `history` feature (see issue #3155), which allows transformers to access parent records directly when `keep_history=True` is set.  
This removes the need to explicitly propagate parent fields through every child transformer, simplifying pipelines and reducing schema clutter.

### Implementation

- When a resource is defined with `keep_history=True`, a `history` dictionary is made available to all subsequent nodes.  
- Only nodes marked with `keep_history=True` contribute their data to this dictionary, ensuring that only the required information is retained.  
- If no node (or any of its parents) uses the history feature, all nodes receive a shared `EMPTY_HISTORY` object. This avoids additional allocations and keeps the overhead negligible, since only a single immutable reference is passed around.  

The design follows a similar approach to the existing `meta` feature for consistency.  
Comprehensive tests have been added to validate the behavior of this new feature.

### Tiny Additional Proposal

As a follow-up improvement, we could simplify function signatures by removing the need for explicit `= None` defaults.  
For example, instead of writing:

```python
def transformer(item, meta=None, history=None):
    ...

```
we could allow:
```python
def transformer(item, meta, history):
    ...

```
This would make transformer definitions cleaner and reduce boilerplate in function signatures.

title: Feat/faster testing
body:
# PR Summary

This PR improves CI and local test execution time by parallelizing test execution. This is achieved thanks to pytest xdist and fully isolating test workers at the filesystem and service level to avoid collision between workers. 

## Changes

- Introduced worker-aware helpers in `tests.utils` to provide a worker-specific test storage root and stable worker ID.  
- Updated tests to consistently use worker-specific storage roots so parallel workers never write to the same filesystem paths.  
- Used the worker ID to isolate external or service-backed resources when filesystem isolation alone is insufficient.  
- Updated load test destinations that rely on global catalogs (e.g. MotherDuck or ducklake) to use worker-specific catalogs to prevent cross-worker conflicts.  
- Increased the number of parallel workers where safe, particularly for remote destinations that scale elastically (e.g. Athena), which were previously the slowest tests.  
- Kept parallelism conservative for services backed by shared or limited execution engines (e.g. Synapse, Databricks), where increasing workers can overwhelm the backend rather than improve performance.  
- Common tests are CPU bound and GitHub-hosted runner constraints have 4 cores fully used. Further improvements  would require increasing the number of CI machines generating more OS/Python/test-suite combinations, reducing testing-matrix readability. Local development machines typically have more than 4 cores (e.g. 12-core setups), allowing the common tests to run in ~5 minutes using the provided fast local test Make targets (`make test-common-p`). Tests can be executed serially with `make test-common`
- Preserved explicit separation between parallel-safe tests and serial-only tests, ensuring that tests with known concurrency constraints are always executed sequentially.
